awd_titl_txt: ARTS: A revisionary monograph of fungi in the genus Fusarium
awd_abstract_narration:
Fungi in the genus Fusarium cause plant, animal, and human diseases, and produce toxins that contaminate food around the world. Despite their importance and ubiquity, the genus needs a complete taxonomic revision. Only about half of the roughly 300 species we know about even have names, as a result many researchers are not able to get satisfying answers about this group. This project will produce a new monograph of Fusarium that provides a complete description of all currently known species in this genus. Importantly, this monograph will provide a direct electronic link with two key resources: 1) Fusarium specimens in major culture collections that are available for further research and 2) databases of DNA sequence data with a sequence-based classification tool. The electronic portability of the monograph will enable connecting to portals for biological diversity such as Encyclopedia of Life and Wikipedia. This resource will also allow the discovery and recognition of new species of Fusarium, even in well-studied environments such as soils and plants. This project will train two PhD students and a postdoctoral scholar, broaden the training of the PIs, and facilitate collaborations with diverse scientists and students from around the world. 

This project will utilize new and existing gene sequence data to inform the first full taxonomic treatment of this key genus in over thirty years. The monograph will include introductory chapters that summarize the biological and ecological diversity of the genus. A Fusarium Basics Guide distilled from the monograph will be aimed at the many individuals who use morphology for identification. Individual species descriptions will be arranged based on evolutionary relationships, and will include morphological, ecological and other information. It will also include links to lists of isolates that are available and the data associated with them. Existing barcode gene sequences of the isolates, as well as existing poorly identified Fusarium sequences, will be curated to correct the taxonomy. This curated information will maximize their impact in studies that utilize sequence-based classification. Of particular importance is providing curated datasets that are accessible to bioinformatics platforms used to classify sequences derived from environmental DNA studies.

por.por_cntn:
Fusarium is one of the most impactful genera in the Fungal Kingdom. It is globally ubiquitous, and one of the most important causes of plant disease. It also produces mycotoxins that poison food and animal feed, and causes rare but potentially deadly infections of humans. At the same time, Fusarium interacts with plants in beneficial ways, is used in industry to produce useful enzymes, and even consumed as a food. This project utilized DNA sequences and other data to provide a taxonomic framework for this genus, focusing on tools that assist the many researchers, clinicians and other personnel who must identify species in medicine, agriculture, and environmental studies. Key to these efforts is a DNA sequence marker translation elongation factor 1-alpha (tef1a), a highly useful tool for species-level identification in this group where traditional methods are inaccurate and time-consuming. We curated and released a new version of FUSARIUM-ID, which individual researchers can easily download and set up on personal computers for sequence-based identification, using both free and commercial software tools. A PhD student supported by the grant utilized tef1a and FUSARIUM-ID to characterize Fusarium communities in plants, capturing diverse species at a higher level of resolution than the kingdom-wide marker ITS. Guides were produced that provide instruction for setting up FUSARIUM-ID (including Spanish translation) and also for interpreting results from BLAST analysis, which often require careful scientific interpretation. We developed in-person workshops on Fusarium, presented in both English and Spanish, that provide workers with basic guidelines for using both microscopic and DNA sequence data for identification and classification. We published a comprehensive phylogenomic phylogeny of the genus, solidifying a practical phylogenetic definition of the genus, that is widely supported by the broad user-base of its taxonomy. We are now completing a revision of the concept of one of the most important Fusarium species, F. oxysporum, which causes devastating wilt diseases on over 100 hosts around the world. This species, which is known only to reproduce clonally, shows lineage structure that has been interpreted to be species structure, but due to the weakness of that inference and its impracticality, we propose that it remain a single species. At the same time, we are providing nested phylogenomic, amplicon-based and tef1a-based identification tools that aid in identification of F. oxysporum isolates to lineage, which can be important in diagnosis of plant and human pathogens.
